title: May Berenbaum
text:
May Roberta Berenbaum (born 1953) is an American <a href="Entomology">entomologist</a> whose research focuses on the chemical interactions between herbivorous insects and their host plants, and the implications of these interactions on the organization of natural communities and the evolution of species. She is particularly interested in <a href="nectar">nectar</a>, plant <a href="phytochemicals">phytochemicals</a>, <a href="honey">honey</a> and <a href="bees">bees</a>, and her research has important implications for <a href="beekeeping">beekeeping</a>. 
She is a member of the <a href="National%20Academy%20of%20Sciences">National Academy of Sciences</a> and was named editor-in-chief of its journal, "<a href="Proceedings%20of%20the%20National%20Academy%20of%20Sciences%20of%20the%20United%20States%20of%20America">Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences</a>" in 2019; she is also a member of the <a href="American%20Philosophical%20Society">American Philosophical Society</a> (1996), and a fellow of the <a href="American%20Academy%20of%20Arts%20and%20Sciences">American Academy of Arts and Sciences</a> (1996). She has held a Maybelle Leland Swanlund Endowed Chair in <a href="entomology">entomology</a> since 2012, which is the highest title a professor can hold at the <a href="University%20of%20Illinois">University of Illinois</a>. In 2014, she was awarded the <a href="National%20Medal%20of%20Science">National Medal of Science</a>. 
Early life and education.
Berenbaum graduated <a href="summa%20cum%20laude">summa cum laude</a>, with a <a href="B.S.">B.S.</a> degree and honors in biology, from <a href="Yale%20University">Yale University</a> in 1975. Berenbaum discovered an interest in entomology after taking a course on terrestrial arthropods only because it fit her schedule, and found a second passion by taking an elective course in plant biochemistry. After attending a research seminar on <a href="chemical%20ecology">chemical ecology</a> by Paul Feeny, she decided to integrate her interests in entomology and botany, and began a PhD supervised by Feeny at <a href="Cornell%20University">Cornell University</a>. Berenbaum received her <a href="Ph.D.">Ph.D.</a> in ecology and <a href="evolutionary%20biology">evolutionary biology</a> in 1980. 
Research.
Berenbaum is known for her research into the chemistry of <a href="honey">honey</a> and its importance as a <a href="functional%20food">functional food</a> for <a href="bees">bees</a> and <a href="wasps">wasps</a> in the superfamily <a href="Apoidea">Apoidea</a>. As of 2021, approximately 20,000 bee species are known, but there are also signs of <a href="Colony%20collapse%20disorder">declines in bee populations</a> in many countries. Berenbaum's research has shown that honey contains <a href="phytochemicals">phytochemicals</a> that help bees to tolerate cold, resist pesticides, fight off infections, heal wounds, and live longer. Important phytochemicals include <a href="p-coumaric%20acid">p-coumaric acid</a>, <a href="quercetin">quercetin</a>, <a href="abscisic%20acid">abscisic acid</a>, <a href="anabasine">anabasine</a>, <a href="caffeine">caffeine</a>, <a href="gallic%20acid">gallic acid</a>, <a href="kaempferol">kaempferol</a>, and <a href="thymol">thymol</a>. Furthermore, sick honeybees will choose among different types of honey and eat the one that contains the phytochemicals that can improve their health.
Berenbaum's work has important implications, suggesting changes to practices in the <a href="beekeeping">beekeeping</a> industry which may help bees to survive. One conclusion is that floral diversity matters: bees that have the opportunity to make honey from a diverse range of flowers will be healthier bees. As well, beekeepers should leave their bees a variety of different honeys, gathered at different times from different plants, so that they have a "honey pharmacy" to choose from when ill.
Career.
Since 1980, Berenbaum has been a member of the faculty of the department of entomology at the <a href="University%20of%20Illinois%20Urbana-Champaign">University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign</a> and has served as head of the department since 1992. In addition to her research, she is devoted to teaching and to fostering <a href="scientific%20literacy">scientific literacy</a>. She teaches a course on Critical Evaluations of Herbal Remedies for advanced biology undergraduates. 
In 1996, she was elected a Fellow of the <a href="American%20Academy%20of%20Arts%20and%20Sciences">American Academy of Arts and Sciences</a> and she was elected a member of the <a href="American%20Philosophical%20Society">American Philosophical Society</a> in the same year. 
She served as the editor of "<a href="Annual%20Review%20of%20Entomology">Annual Review of Entomology</a>" from 1997 until 2018, and was named editor-in-chief of "<a href="Proceedings%20of%20the%20National%20Academy%20of%20Sciences%20of%20the%20United%20States%20of%20America">Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences USA</a>" in 2019. 
She has written numerous magazine articles, as well as books about insects for the general public:
Berenbaum has also gained some measure of fame as the organizer of the <a href="Insect%20Fear%20Film%20Festival">Insect Fear Film Festival</a> at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, an annual celebration of <a href="Hollywood">Hollywood</a>'s entomological excesses.
